text: it's mark Wiens in Bangkok Thailand and
I'm absolutely thrilled because right
now I'm going to be making the recipe
for one of my absolute favorite dishes
in Thailand and probably the entire
world
it's called goon pancetta and goon is
the Thai word for shrimp and then Saha
is the Thai word for this gorgeous
ingredient known in english as stink
bean and then known also as pet eye I
think it's also known as bitter bean or
twisted or cluster bean anyway this is
one of the absolute gems of the world
that grows naturally we're going to stir
fry this up with some shrimp and some
curry paste and it's going to be
absolutely delicious
for this recipe you'll need the stink
beans of course and I used six pods
which probably came to about half a cup
of peeled stink beans then about six to
eight kaffir lime leaves two heaping
tablespoons of southern Thai curry paste
about 400 grams of shrimp and the
medium-sized ones work really well for
this recipe and basically most of the
seasoning is already in the paste so you
don't need too much extra but you will
need a little extra spoon of oyster
sauce about a half a teaspoon of shrimp
paste and about a half a tablespoon of
sugar and then finally a few tablespoons
of oil for frying a set thought is a
very readily available ingredient in
much of Southeast Asia but I'm not so
sure if it's available in other parts of
the world so if you cannot find stink
beans you can substitute a kind of a
crisp vegetable like Chinese long beans
or even green beans would would work but
if you can find stink beans
it is the absolute ultimate ingredient
so do try to find them if you can the
first step is to prepare all your
ingredients and get them ready to
stir-fry stink beans grow in a really
hard twisted pod and the outer skin is
actually really tough so the easiest
thing to do is take a sharp knife and
slice the beans in half from the outside
and do this to all your stink bean pods
then you can go back with just your
fingers and just kind of pull out the
stink beans from the shell there's also
an inner cream-colored film or skin on
the beans and you want to peel that off
as well
and throw it away and then what you're
left with is a nice beautiful
almond-shaped stink bean next onto the
shrimp you just want to pluck off the
head and peel the shell of the body and
then make sure you slice it down the
backbone and devein it now the thai
style is to peel the full body of the
shrimp but leave the small tail on so
you can do this as well that's it for
the preparation everything else should
be ready to go now turn on your fire and
you want a medium-high heat you can add
2 to 3 tablespoons of oil but you don't
want to skimp on the oil or your curry
paste will get dried out and stick make
sure your oil is sizzling and then
gently add 2 heaping tablespoon
of southern Thai curry paste also you
can immediately add about half a
teaspoon of shrimp paste then start
frying the curry paste making sure it
doesn't stick so you want to fry it
pretty hard
scraping the bottom of your pan keep
frying the curry paste for about 30
seconds and it's going to become really
fragrant but you don't want it to burn
then toss in all 400 grams of your
shrimp and keep stir frying continuously
for about 20 to 30 seconds now if it
starts to get dry you can toss in a
splash of water then in goes your stink
beans and keep frying for about another
30 seconds and keep working your wok
really fast then you can add about half
a tablespoon of oyster sauce and about
half a tablespoon of sugar stir fry all
that together and again if it starts to
get too dry you can always add in a
splash of water but keep stir frying
until you can see the shrimp are just
about fully cooked and they're starting
to get firm but not overcooked
okay now the final step is to take six
to eight kaffir lime leaves and just
tear them off the stem with your hands
carrying them will bring out their
wonderful lemony limey flavor stir-fry
for just a few more seconds and your
shrimp and your stink beans should be
cooked but not overcook and then take
your pan off the heat and you can
immediately dish it onto a serving plate
by this time your mouth should be
watering and you should be really hungry
and ready to eat so if you remembered to
cook a pot of rice beforehand that is a
great thing to do okay so the cumin pods
at ah is ready you can just see these
gorgeous prawns the pet I saw and then
just up that incredibly wonderful
southern Thai curry paste blend fried
that we made okay
I can't talk anymore I gotta eat right
now a shrimp and make sure I get lots of
gravy in this bite shrimp rice
that is just that just melts my heart
that is stunningly good
I can taste all those chilies that we
ground up the turmeric and then the the
citta the dusting beans they're a little
bit bitter but the texture is just
amazing it's like a it's like a crisp
almost like a raw green bean texture so
it has that really fresh crispness and
then just coated in that chili
stir-fried chili and garlic this is just
one of the world's finest dishes and I I
wish you could be sitting here eating
with me right now I hope you enjoyed
this recipe for gong pancetta which is
one of my absolute favorite Thai dishes
and favorite dishes in the entire world
thank you so much for watching this
recipe and sure to give it a thumbs up
leave a comment below share this video
with a friend and if you can find stink
beans you just have got to try this
recipe
